Text.Chief Complaint: Has experienced abdominal pain for three months
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports upper abdominal pain accompanied by radiating back pain, with pain severity gradually increasing. Pain score is 4 out of 10, with no impact on sleep. Text.Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain lasting one day.
Text.Present Illness: The patient experienced sudden severe pain in the upper abdomen one day ago without any apparent cause. The pain was constant, without episodic worsening or radiation to other areas. Symptoms included nausea and vomiting six times, with the vomitus consisting of gastric contents totaling about 1000 milliliters, containing no blood or worms.
Text.Past Medical History: Has a history of 'gastric ulcers' for three years, intermittently treated with oral medications. Denies history of 'hypertension, diabetes,' etc. No known drug or food allergies, no history of trauma or major surgery, and unclear history of vaccinations.
Text.Examinations:
Complete blood count shows: white blood cells at 2.46*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage at 79.0%, lymphocyte percentage at 14.0%, neutrophils count at 1.95*10^9/L, lymphocytes count at 0.34*10^9/L, hemoglobin at 159.00 g/L. 

 Biochemical report indicates: total protein at 45.7 g/L, albumin at 22.9 g/L, globulin at 23.60 g/L. 

 Upper abdominal CT: <\image00002.jpg>.
Text.Diagnosis: 1. Upper gastrointestinal perforation, 2. Cholecystolithiasis, cholecystitis, liver cyst, 3. Thickened ascending colon, 4. Acute diffuse peritonitis
Text.Treatment: Surgical repair of gastric pyloric perforation

Image.00002.jpg: Free air and fluid in the abdominal cavity, blurred fat stranding in the intestinal lumen, suggesting hollow visceral perforation. 2. Liver cyst 3. Gallstones, cholecystitis 4. Thickened ascending colon, further examination recommended

 Biochemical report indicates: total protein at 45.7 g/L, albumin at 22.9 g/L, globulin at 23.60 g/L. 

 Upper abdominal CT: <\image00002.jpg>.

The patient presented with sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain lasting for one day, accompanied by nausea and vomiting of gastric contents without blood or worms.

Past Medical History:

Examination Items and Results:
- Abdominal ultrasound: Fluid accumulation in the abdomen
- Upper abdominal CT scan: Mass in the liver

Diagnosis:
Based on the examination results, the patient was diagnosed with fluid accumulation in the abdomen and a mass in the liver, which could potentially be a tumor.

Treatment Plan:
Further diagnostic procedures were recommended to determine the cause of the fluid accumulation and the nature of the liver mass. A biopsy of the liver mass was suggested to make a definitive diagnosis. Depending on the results of the biopsy, further treatment options such as surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy may be considered. Additionally, supportive care measures such as pain management and nutritional support may be necessary. Further follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and progress.

Text.Chief Complaint: Upper abdominal distension and pain for 7 hours
Text.Present Illness: The patient consumed a high-fat diet last night and began experiencing pain in the upper abdomen around 9 AM today, primarily in the upper left quadrant. The abdominal pain is continuous, severe, and intolerable, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. There was no significant relief of abdominal pain after vomiting.
Text.Past Medical History: None.
Text.Examinations:
White blood cell count is 15.14 x 10^9/L, electrolytes are largely normal, triglycerides are 9.44 mmol/L, liver and kidney functions are normal, calcitonin is normal, and blood glucose is normal.  

  Upper abdominal CT shows: <\image00003.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Treatment includes omeprazole for acid suppression, low molecular weight heparin for lipid reduction, somatostatin to inhibit pancreatic enzyme secretion, fluid replacement to maintain electrolyte balance, and moxifloxacin for anti-infection.

Image.00003.jpg: Consistent with pancreatitis with peripancreatic effusion, and fatty liver.

Text.Chief Complaint: Abdominal pain and diarrhea for 3 days
Text.Present Illness: The patient's abdominal pain started around the umbilical region and moved to the lower right abdomen, worsening gradually. The pain is sharp and exacerbated by movement and eating. Oral painkillers like acetaminophen provide partial relief. The pain is associated with low-grade fever and decreased appetite. The patient reports watery stools five times per day, with no mucus or blood. Diarrhea started after taking antibiotics for a recent upper respiratory infection.
Text.Past Medical History: History of diabetes, well-controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. No history of surgeries. Smoker for 15 years. No family history of hereditary gastrointestinal diseases.
Text.Examinations:
Palpation: Abdomen soft with diffuse tenderness, most notable in the right iliac fossa with rebound tenderness.  

  Rovsing's sign: positive. Complete blood count shows elevated white blood cells and inflammatory markers (including ESR and CRP).  

  Liver and kidney functions normal. 

  Abdominal CT: <\image00006.jpg>
Text.Treatment: Limited cecum resection with appendectomy

Image.00006.jpg: Thickened colon wall with edematous folds suggesting pseudomembranous colitis. A 6cm lesion in the cecum, well-defined, with uniform fat density and no solid components.

The CT scan of your abdomen reveals two abnormalities:

(A) A solid mass in the left kidney, which could indicate a renal tumor or cyst.
(B) A large mass in the right lobe of the liver, which could suggest a hepatic tumor or abscess.

Given these findings, it appears that you may have a malignancy involving both the kidney and liver. Further testing, such as biopsies, would be needed to confirm the nature of these masses and determine the appropriate course of treatment. In the meantime, we will monitor your symptoms closely and discuss potential treatment options once more information becomes available.

Please come back for another consultation after the biopsy results are ready, and we can discuss the next steps in detail. In the meantime, try to rest and maintain a healthy diet to support your overall health. If you experience any new symptoms or worsening of existing ones, please contact us immediately.

Diagnosis:
Based on the examination results, John Doe is suspected to have a malignancy involving both the kidney and liver. Further testing, such as biopsies, is required to confirm the nature of the masses and determine the appropriate course of treatment.

Text.Chief Complaint: Two months post-acute pancreatitis recovery, experiencing abdominal bloating and decreased appetite for half a month.
Text.Present Illness: The patient developed persistent dull pain in the upper abdomen, particularly in the upper left quadrant, two months ago following overeating. Accompanied by nausea, vomiting of gastric contents, and developed generalized skin jaundice and dark urine. No chills, high fever, cough, phlegm, or breathing difficulties. Diagnosed at our hospital with acute pancreatitis and steatohepatitis.
Text.Past Medical History: History of acute pancreatitis two months ago treated with medication. Denies history of surgeries, trauma, drug allergies, and denies contact with infectious diseases such as tuberculosis.
Text.Examinations:
Laboratory findings show: ALT: 65.2 U/L, AST: 32.0 U/L, GGT: 126.0 U/L, TBIL: 22.5 umol/L, DBIL: 10.3 umol/L, IBIL: 12.2 umol/L, serum amylase 217 U/L.  

 CT shows: <\image00007.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Administered famotidine 20 mg in 100 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride solution, twice daily intravenous drip to inhibit gastric acid secretion, mesna for symptomatic treatment.

Image.00007.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, no abnormal density in the parenchyma, no dilation in intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, normal size of the gallbladder, no clear positive stones. Pancreas is full, streak shadows around the pancreas, a round-like low-density shadow in front of the pancreas head, approximately 3.3*2.6 cm. Normal morphology, size, and density of the spleen. No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal area.

history.doctor:
Alright. Based on your symptoms and past medical history, I would like to recommend some medical examinations to help us better understand what might be causing your thumb pain and limited movement. 

Firstly, we need to rule out any potential bone fractures or joint dislocations. Therefore, I suggest getting an X-ray of your right thumb.

Secondly, since you mentioned that the pain is persistent and not tied to any specific activity, we also need to consider the possibility of nerve compression or inflammation. In this case, I recommend undergoing an electromyography (EMG) test to assess the electrical activity of the muscles and nerves around your thumb.

Lastly, if these initial tests don't reveal anything conclusive, we may also consider additional imaging studies such as MRI or CT scans to get a more detailed view of the soft tissues surrounding your thumb.

Once we have all the necessary information from these tests, we can then discuss appropriate treatment options tailored specifically to your condition. Please schedule these appointments with our office staff, and we'll take care of everything else.

history.doctor:
Thank you for providing the X-ray image. From the image, it appears that there is no fracture or dislocation in your right thumb. However, I notice that there is some narrowing at the base of your thumb joint, which could indicate arthritis. This type of arthritis is called basal joint arthritis and is common in people who use their hands frequently for tasks that require strength, such as gripping or pinching.

Based on your symptoms, past medical history, and the X-ray findings, I believe you are likely suffering from basal joint arthritis in your right thumb. This condition can cause pain, stiffness, and reduced mobility in the affected joint.

To manage your symptoms and improve function, I recommend several steps:

1. **Rest and Ice:** Give your thumb adequate rest and apply ice packs to reduce swelling and pain.

2. **Therapy Exercises:** Engage in exercises that focus on strengthening the muscles around the thumb joint and improving flexibility. A physical therapist can guide you through proper exercise techniques.

3. **Splinting:** Wearing a splint during activities that aggravate your thumb pain can help protect the joint and alleviate discomfort.

4. **Pain Management:** Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen can help manage your pain. If needed, your healthcare provider may prescribe stronger medications or recommend other forms of pain management.

5. **Surgery:** If conservative treatments fail to provide relief, surgery may be considered as a last resort option. This typically involves procedures to realign or fuse the affected joint.

Please keep in mind that managing arthritis requires patience and persistence. It may take time to find the right combination of therapies that work best for you. Regular check-ins with your healthcare provider will help ensure that your condition is monitored closely, and adjustments to your treatment plan can be made as needed.

Medical Case Report

Patient Information:
Age: 53 years old
Gender: Female

Present Illness:
The patient reports experiencing pain and limited movement in her right thumb for approximately one year. She mentions that the pain is persistent and not tied to any specific activity.

Past Medical History:
The patient has a hammer deformity of the right little finger, which has been present for ten years.

Examination Items and Results:
X-ray of the right thumb revealed no fractures or dislocations but showed narrowing at the base of the thumb joint, indicating possible basal joint arthritis.

Diagnosis:
Basal Joint Arthritis of the Right Thumb

Treatment Plan:
1. Rest and Ice: Provide the thumb with adequate rest and apply ice packs to reduce swelling and pain.
2. Therapy Exercises: Engage in exercises focusing on strengthening the muscles around the thumb joint and improving flexibility under the guidance of a physical therapist.
3. Splinting: Wear a splint during activities that aggravate thumb pain to protect the joint and alleviate discomfort.
4. Pain Management: Use over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen to manage pain; prescription medication or alternative pain management methods may be considered if needed.
5. Surgery: Consider surgical intervention as a last resort if conservative treatments fail to provide relief. Surgical options include joint realignment or fusion procedures.

Regular follow-ups with the healthcare provider are essential to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Information:

Age: 66 years old
Gender: Female

Present Illness:
The patient presented with a one-day history of abdominal pain that began after consuming alcohol. The pain was described as a continuous bloating sensation that worsened over time and was accompanied by radiating pain in the back. Changing positions did not alleviate the discomfort. The patient denied experiencing changes in bowel movements, nausea, vomiting, travel, or consumption of unusual foods.

Past Medical History:
No significant past medical history was reported.

Examination Items and Results:
Physical examination revealed tenderness in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Blood work showed elevated liver enzymes and leukocytosis. Urinalysis was normal. Imaging studies were ordered, which included an ultrasound and CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.

Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms, laboratory findings, and imaging studies, the diagnosis was acute cholecystitis secondary to gallstones.

Treatment Plan:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and pain management. She underwent cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal) via laparoscopic surgery. Postoperatively, she recovered well and was discharged home on oral antibiotics and pain medication. Follow-up appointments were scheduled for further evaluation and monitoring.

The CT scan revealed a small renal cyst in your left kidney and mild diverticulosis in your colon, but no acute pathology was found. While these findings may not be the direct cause of your current symptoms, they are important to note for future reference.

Based on the available information, it appears that your abdominal pain could be due to an infection or inflammation in your digestive system. Further evaluation and treatment may be required depending on the severity of your symptoms and other factors. Further evaluation and treatment may be required depending on the severity of the symptoms and other factors. A referral to a gastroenterologist for a more detailed assessment and appropriate management plan is recommended.

Patient Information:

- Age: 45 years old
- Gender: Male

Present Illness:

The patient presented with persistent upper abdominal pain lasting one day, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The pain was described as continuous and severe, located in the upper abdomen and radiating towards the back. The patient reported no fever or changes in bowel movements and否认了最近的旅行或食用不寻常食物的经历。

Past Medical History:

No significant past medical history was reported.

Examination Items and Results:

1. Physical Exam: Normal findings
2. Vital Signs: Normal readings
3. Rectal Exam: Normal findings
4. Ultrasound: Normal findings
5. Stool Analysis: Normal findings

Diagnostic Tests and Results:

1. Abdominal CT: Normal findings
2. Complete Blood Count:
	* White blood cells: 10.19*10^9/L
	* Neutrophils: 83.30%
	* Lymphocytes: 10.40%
	* Neutrophil count: 8.49*10^9/L
3. Urinalysis:
	* Ketones: +3
	* Glucose: +4
	* Protein: +3
4. Bicarbonate: 12.81 mmol/L
5. Blood Sugar: 14.44 mmol/L

Diagnosis:

Based on the patient's symptoms, medical history, and test results, the patient is diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The high ketone levels in the urine, elevated glucose, and low bicarbonate levels suggest metabolic acidosis. The CT scan did not reveal any abnormalities, ruling out issues like gallstones or pancreatitis. The slightly elevated white blood cell count indicates possible inflammation or infection.

Treatment Plan:

1. Consultation with a specialist for further evaluation and treatment.
2. Proper management of diabetes.
3. Addressing any underlying infections.
4. Monitoring blood sugar levels.
5. Staying hydrated.
6. Seeking immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or do not improve.

Text.Chief Complaint: Seizures and fall after stopping medication for meningioma and epilepsy diagnosed a year ago, with pain and bleeding from the right eyebrow arch for one hour.
Text.Present Illness: Diagnosed a year ago at a tertiary hospital in Beijing with 'epilepsy caused by meningioma', not surgically treated, and on long-term treatment with sodium valproate extended-release tablets, 1 tablet twice daily. Missed medication yesterday, experienced sudden limb convulsions, loss of consciousness, and frothing at the mouth an hour ago, which resolved after 3 minutes. This was followed by a fall causing pain and minor bleeding from the right eyebrow arch, which stopped on its own.

Text.Chief Complaint: Chronic constipation for 20 years, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distension, and cessation of gas and bowel movements for 3 days.
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports chronic constipation starting 20 years ago without an apparent cause, with hard stools occurring every 3 to 5 days and difficulty defecating, but without pain unless attempting to defecate, and no bloody or purulent stools. Previously diagnosed locally as 'constipation' and improved with oral laxatives (name and dosage unknown); intermittently medicated over 20 years. Constipation recurred 3 days ago, accompanied by episodic severe pain in the right upper abdomen, no radiation, and accompanied by nausea and vomiting five times of gastric contents, totaling about 1000 milliliters, without blood or worms. Abdominal pain slightly reduced after vomiting, accompanied by abdominal distension and cessation of gas and stool passage.
Text.Past Medical History: 20-year history of constipation.
Text.Examinations:
Upright abdominal plain film: <\image00018.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: white blood cells 9.34*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage 88.60%, lymphocyte percentage 7.50%, neutrophils 8.27*10^9/L, lymphocytes 0.70*10^9/L.
Text.Treatment: Upon hospital admission, comprehensive tests were performed including continuous gastrointestinal decompression, warm soapy water enema of 800 ml, maintaining fluid and electrolyte and acid-base balance. The patient's underlying condition includes deficiency of yin and body fluids, dry and hard stools, lack of facial radiance, pale lips, and a fine and rough pulse. In traditional Chinese medicine, diagnosed as blood and yin deficiency, treatment should nourish yin and moisten dryness. Administered intestinal moistening pills and modified Shengjiang Chengqi Tang via gastric tube, 150 ml, tube clamped for 2 hours, resulting in substantial bowel movement the next day, symptoms and signs resolved.

Image.00018.jpg: No free gas under the diaphragm, intestinal gas and dilation in the right upper abdomen with a large gas-fluid level visible, no clear positive stone shadows in the path of both kidneys and ureters, both abdominal fat lines are still clear. Indicates right upper abdominal intestinal dilation and gas accumulation, large gas-fluid level visible, correlated clinically.

Medical Case Report

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 81 years old
Gender: Female

Present Illness:
The patient presented with chronic constipation, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distension lasting for three days. The patient reported no changes in her appetite or eating habits, but she did experience decreased food intake due to nausea and vomiting. She also reported a history of chronic constipation for the past 20 years.

Past Medical History:
The patient has a history of chronic constipation for the past 20 years.

(6) Endoscopy: Normal
(7) Colonoscopy: Normal

Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, along with the results of the abdominal X-ray, it was initially suspected that the patient may have a blockage in her intestines. However, the CT scan came back normal, indicating that there were no structural issues. Further testing with endoscopy and colonoscopy also showed no abnormalities. Therefore, the exact cause of the patient's symptoms remains unclear.

Treatment Plan:
Given the lack of clear diagnosis, the patient was recommended to continue taking oral laxatives as prescribed and maintain a healthy diet to promote regular bowel movements. A referral to a gastroenterologist specializing in digestive disorders was also suggested for further evaluation and management. If symptoms persist, additional diagnostic tests may be necessary to determine the underlying cause.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain in the upper right abdomen one day after cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports that one month ago, she underwent a 'cholecystectomy and choledocholithotomy' due to 'gallbladder stones and common bile duct stones' at another hospital, with good postoperative recovery. One day ago, she experienced sudden severe continuous pain in the upper right abdomen without a clear cause, which was unbearable and radiated to the right shoulder and back, accompanied by nausea and vomiting of gastric contents without bile or coffee-ground material. The pain did not lessen after vomiting and was accompanied by fever with a body temperature of 37.8°C, no chills, and no jaundice.
Text.Past Medical History: History of gallbladder and common bile duct stones for 6 years, long-term intermittent medication use, underwent cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: Flat abdomen, localized tenderness in the upper right abdomen and mid upper abdomen, no rebound tenderness or muscle tension, tympanic abdomen on percussion, bowel sounds 4-6 times per minute, no splashing or metallic sounds heard. 

  CT: <\image00019.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: WBC: 5.98*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage: 71.00%, lymphocyte percentage: 22.30%; neutrophil count: 3.97*10^9/L, lymphocyte count: 1.24*10^9/L.
Text.Treatment: Treatment with cefoperazone sodium and sulbactam sodium, and omeprazole injections to inhibit gastric acid secretion; intravenous phenobarbital for spasmolytic and analgesic treatment.

Image.00019.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, with punctate low-density areas in the parenchyma, no dilation of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. Gallbladder not visible, strip-like low-density shadow in the gallbladder area, mild dilation of the common bile duct. Normal morphology, size, and density of the spleen and pancreas. No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal areas, no fluid in the abdominal cavity.

Patient Information:

  * Age: 51 years old
  * Gender: Female

Present Illness:

  * Pain in upper right abdomen for one day
  * Nausea and vomiting of gastric contents
  * Pain radiating to right shoulder and back
  * Mild fever (37.8°C)

Past Medical History:

  * Gallbladder removal and common bile duct exploration one month prior due to gallstones and common bile duct stones

Examination Items and Results:

  * Abdominal ultrasound: Flat abdomen with localized tenderness in upper right and mid-upper abdomen regions; no abnormalities found
  * Blood tests: White blood cell count slightly elevated with neutrophilia; lymphocyte count within normal range
  * CT scan: Inflammation or swelling in area surrounding liver and bile ducts

Diagnosis:

  * Bile duct obstruction or infection

Treatment Plan:

  * Additional testing through either endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) or magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
  * Treatment options depend on results of additional testing, but may include antibiotics or surgical intervention to remove blockage.

Text.Chief Complaint: Abdominal pain for 5 hours
Text.Present Illness: The patient experienced abdominal pain without a clear cause 5 hours ago, affecting the entire abdomen. The pain is persistent with severe episodic flare-ups, accompanied by nausea and vomiting multiple times, with the vomitus consisting of stomach contents.
Text.Past Medical History: None
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: Abdominal distension, abdominal muscle tension, generalized abdominal tenderness, no rebound tenderness, no palpable mass, liver and spleen not palpable below the rib cage, no costovertebral angle tenderness on the right, negative Murphy's sign, negative shifting dullness, bowel sounds at 2 per minute. 

  CT: <\image00021.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Removal of contaminants from the abdominal cavity and dry fecal masses from the proximal intestine. Repair of colonic perforation, partial resection of the rectosigmoid colon, creation of a sigmoid colostomy, and abdominal lavage and drainage.

history.doctor:
Thank you for providing the test results. Based on your symptoms, medical history, and the negative test results, it appears that you may be suffering from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). IBS is a common disorder that affects the large intestine and can cause symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloating, gas, constipation, and diarrhea. Your symptoms, including reduced frequency of bowel movements, flatulence, acid reflux, burping, and nausea, are consistent with IBS.

To manage your symptoms, I recommend making lifestyle changes such as increasing fiber intake, staying hydrated, exercising regularly, and managing stress levels. Additionally, over-the-counter medications such as antispasmodics or laxatives may help alleviate your symptoms.

If your symptoms persist despite these measures, we may consider additional diagnostic testing or referral to a specialist. Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain in the chest and abdomen following a vehicle accident 2 hours ago
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports pain in the chest and abdomen that started 2 hours ago following a vehicle accident. The chest pain is localized to the left side, worsens with deep breathing and coughing, accompanied by mild respiratory difficulty, but no hemoptysis. The abdominal pain is a continuous dull ache, localized to the upper left quadrant, without episodic worsening.
Text.Past Medical History: None
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: Thoracic cage without deformity, no evident redness or swelling on the left chest wall, apparent tenderness on palpation from the 3rd to 12th ribs, positive bone crepitus, positive compression test; abdomen flat, mild tenderness on light pressure in the upper left quadrant, no rebound tenderness or muscle rigidity, mild costovertebral angle tenderness over the left kidney, no tenderness over liver or right kidney area, negative shifting dullness, bowel sounds 4-5 times per minute, no splashing or metallic sounds heard, negative abdominal puncture.  

 Abdominal CT: <\image00024.jpg>.  

 Chest CT: 1. Left-sided pneumohydrothorax, band-like opacities in the lower lobes of both lungs; 2. Small nodules in the right middle and upper lobes; 3. Dilatation of the ascending aorta, aortic wall calcification; 4. Bilateral hilar lymph node calcification; 5. Small amount of effusion in the right thoracic cavity, localized thickening of the right pleura; 6. Fractures of the left 3rd to 12th ribs.
Text.Diagnosis: Blunt trauma to the thoracoabdominal region, abdominal effusion
Text.Treatment: Management includes nil by mouth, fluid replenishment, antibiotics, and nutritional support.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Information:

* Age: 57 years old
* Gender: Male

Present Illness:

The patient presented with intermittent upper abdominal pain and vomiting for the past five days, which worsened two hours prior to their visit. They reported no specific triggers for the pain and no recent travel or dietary changes. The patient also disclosed a history of gallbladder issues, including gallbladder inflammation for over 30 years, cholecystectomy 10 years ago, and common bile duct stone removal six years ago.

Past Medical History:

* Gallbladder inflammation for over 30 years
* Cholecystectomy 10 years ago
* Common bile duct stone removal six years ago

Examination Items and Results:

* Physical examination revealed tenderness in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen.
* Electrocardiogram was normal.
* Abdominal ultrasound did not reveal any specific findings.
* Abdominal CT scan showed abnormalities in the liver and pancreas area.

Diagnosis:

Based on the patient's symptoms, past medical history, and examination results, the patient is likely experiencing a complication related to their previous gallbladder surgery or common bile duct stone removal. Further evaluation is needed to determine the exact cause of the symptoms.

Treatment Plan:

* The patient will undergo additional medical examinations, including blood tests and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), to evaluate the liver and pancreas abnormalities identified on the CT scan.
* Depending on the results of these evaluations, further management options may include antibiotics, biliary stenting, or surgical intervention if necessary.

Thank you for answering those questions. Based on what you've told me, it sounds like you may be experiencing migraines. Migraines are a type of headache that can cause intense pain, usually in the head's back or sides. They can also cause sensitivity to light and sound, nausea, and vomiting.

To confirm the diagnosis, we'll need to perform some additional tests. We'll start with a physical exam, including checking your blood pressure and heart rate. We may also recommend imaging tests like an MRI or CT scan to rule out other potential causes of your headaches.

In the meantime, there are some things you can try at home to manage your symptoms. For example, you might find relief from applying heat or cold to your head, taking over-the-counter pain medication like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, or practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation.

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns, and we'll work together to develop a treatment plan that works best for you.

- Gender: Female

Present Illness:

The patient has been experiencing episodic headaches and dizziness for six months, which have worsened over the past month. She denies having any limb numbness or weakness, seizures, consciousness disturbances, or slurred speech. Her vision and hearing remain normal, but her sleep patterns have been disrupted due to the discomfort from the headaches. Her appetite remains consistent, but she experiences nausea during the headaches.

Past Medical History:

The patient denies having any chronic diseases such as hypertension or diabetes. She also denies any infectious diseases like hepatitis or tuberculosis, and she hasn't had any close contact with infectious cases. There's no history of significant trauma, and she doesn't have any known allergies to food or drugs. Furthermore, she hasn't had any blood transfusions, and her vaccination history is unclear.

Examination Items and Results:

A basic neurological exam was conducted, and no abnormalities were found. Imaging studies such as a CT scan or MRI were recommended to rule out any structural issues in the brain.

Diagnosis:

Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, it is possible that she is experiencing primary headache disorders such as tension-type headaches or migraine headaches. However, further testing is needed to rule out secondary causes of headaches such as structural issues in the brain.

Treatment Plan:

The patient will undergo imaging studies such as a CT scan or MRI to rule out any structural issues in the brain. If no structural issues are found, then the patient will likely be prescribed medication to manage her headaches and dizziness. This may include over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen, or prescription medications such as triptans or anti-nausea medication. Lifestyle modifications such as reducing stress, getting regular exercise, and maintaining a healthy diet may also be recommended to help manage the patient's symptoms.

Text.Chief Complaint: Coughing, expectorating phlegm, and chest pain for 2 months, worsening over the last half month.
Text.Present Illness: Two months prior to admission, after catching cold, the patient started experiencing coughing and expectoration, mainly in fits lasting about several minutes that would resolve spontaneously. He produces a small amount of white viscous sputum, accompanied by bilateral chest wall pain, predominantly on the right side, noticeable during deep inhalation and unrelated to physical activity. No chills, fever, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, hoarseness, chest tightness, palpitations, night sweats, hemoptysis, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, aversion to oils, poor appetite, jaundice, or urinary symptoms like frequency, urgency, or pain. No abdominal distension or pain, diarrhea. The patient self-medicated with 'cough medicine' (specific treatment unknown to the patient), but noticed no significant improvement. Symptoms worsened half a month ago, and intermittent self-medication with 'penicillin' did not relieve the symptoms.
Text.Past Medical History: Generally in moderate health, underwent surgery for cervical spondylosis over a year ago with metal implantation. A smoker for 40 years, averaging 20 cigarettes/day, has not quit. Drank alcohol for 40 years, mainly strong spirits, averaging about 250 ml/day, quit 2 years ago.

Antibiotics adjusted to meropenem in combination with vancomycin.

Text.Chief Complaint: Presenting to our hospital due to 'fever and headache for 7 days'.
Text.Present Illness: The patient started experiencing fever 7 days ago, with temperatures reaching up to 37.5°C, and headaches affecting the entire head, occurring intermittently and lasting about 30 minutes each. The headaches, sometimes unbearable, did not respond well to oral pain medication occasionally and did not show a clear correlation with body position. Headaches occurred even when her temperature was normal.
Text.Past Medical History: 45 days ago, the patient had a fever peaking at 39°C with chills, tested positive for the novel coronavirus, followed by a decrease in temperature. 15 days ago, she again developed a fever reaching 38°C, with no cough or expectoration, testing positive for coronavirus antigen. Intermittently took ibuprofen. Denies any history of diabetes, kidney diseases, surgeries, trauma, blood transfusions, and has been vaccinated against COVID-19.
Text.Examinations:
Cranial CT: <\image00032.jpg>.  

 First lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 300 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 420×10^6/L, red blood cells 140×10^6/L, white blood cells 280×10^6/L, 80% polymorphonuclear cells, 20% mononuclear cells.  

 CSF biochemistry: Protein 0.64 g/L, glucose 2.0 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 8.4 mmol/L), lactate 2.4 mmol/L. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus.  

 Second lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 150 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 190×10^6/L, red blood cells 90×10^6/L, white blood cells 100×10^6/L, 64% polymorphonuclear cells, 36% mononuclear cells. Biochemistry: Protein 0.34 g/L, glucose 2.4 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 5.2 mmol/L), lactate 1.8 mmol/L. Adenosine deaminase in CSF 2.4 U/L, in blood 24 U/L. No bacteria seen on Gram stain, no acid-fast bacilli on acid-fast stain. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus. CSF culture showed no bacterial growth. Tuberculosis infection T-cell test negative.  

 CSF cytology: Abnormal, predominantly lymphocytic.
Text.Treatment: Treatment includes doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 5 months, rifampin 0.6g twice daily for 5 months, and ceftriaxone 2g twice daily intravenously for infection control and symptomatic treatment.

 CSF biochemistry: Protein 0.64 g/L, glucose 2.0 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 8.4 mmol/L), lactate 2.4 mmol/L. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus.  

 Second lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 150 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 190×10^6/L, red blood cells 90×10^6/L, white blood cells 100×10^6/L, 64% polymorphonuclear cells, 36% mononuclear cells. 1. Pain relief medication: Take over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen to alleviate your headache.
2. Hydration: Drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration caused by vomiting.
3. Rest: Get adequate rest and avoid triggers that may worsen your symptoms, such as bright lights or loud noises.
